title: Go Inside a Room That Lets You Hear Your Nervous System
intro: Step into a room so quiet you can hear your own heartbeat—and your nervous system.

transcript.author: Seth Cluett
transcript.text: This experiment just pops a balloon. And normally, when a balloon would pop, you’d hear [makes an exploding noise]—the whole room just kind of expand, right?
[Pops a balloon inside a normal room, making a loud noise.]

transcript.author: Rachel Feltman
transcript.text: Ooh!

transcript.author: Kelso Harper
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Rachel Feltman
transcript.text: [Laughs.] Yeah.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Pretty loud.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah, pretty loud [laughs].

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: But in this room there’s none of that. So you’re gonna hear it as a very sharp sound that just disappears completely.
[Pops a balloon inside an anechoic chamber, making a sharp noise that dissipates immediately.]

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Ooh!

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Welcome to the anechoic chamber. Watch your step.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Whoa [laughs].
Wow, it is already super quiet in here [laughs].

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And it’s gonna get even more quiet when we close the door.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Cool.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: [Walks to the chamber entrance and closes the outer and inner doors.] How’s that?

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: It did get a lot more quiet, yeah [laughs].

Welcome to Science Quickly. I’m Rachel Feltman, and today I’m here with Seth Cluett at Nokia Bell Labs. And you may notice if you’re listening to this, or if you’re watching it, that there’s some interesting stuff going on with the sound. Seth, would you tell us more about why that is?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Yeah, so we are in the historic anechoic chamber at Bell Labs. It is a room that absorbs 99.999 percent of sound-wave propagation and eliminates sound from the outside almost entirely. It is anechoic, meaning it lacks echo. So an anechoic chamber is intended to absorb as close to 100 percent of incidental reflection as you can possibly do.

This room, as you kinda look around, is a [roughly] 30-by-30 cube with a wire mesh a third up from the floor. You might ask yourself, like, “Why is it a third up from the floor, not in the center?” And the answer is that you want the experiment to happen as close to the middle as possible.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Because the one place where it’s scientifically feasible to measure sound exactly is in the center of the cube because the distance to the walls and the reflections are equal in that case.

The building is a shell that has [roughly] two-foot-thick walls and an air gap and then another wall, and that air gap separates the sound waves from the outside. And then inside the room there are these [roughly] four-foot wedge panels in groups of three in an offset kind of orthogonal pattern—a, a grid pattern. They capture the sound waves before they’re able to reflect back. So they, they come to a kind of inverted point in the inside of the wall, and when sound gets into that point it kind of bounces back and forth on the diagonal, and by the time it gets to the outside of the wedge there’s no more sound energy left to reflect.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm, so when you’re in this totally quiet space what kinds of things can you feel and perceive in your body?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Yeah, I think most people feel a kind of pressure against their ears first.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: It sort of feels like the air is heavy or thick. Then, then you start to notice a kind of low pulse and realize that’s your heart beating and you can hear it in the air, in, in addition to through your body. And for most people you can even hear a high pitch, and you think, “Oh, I have tinnitus,” or “There’s something wrong with my hearing.” You’re actually hearing your nervous system ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Wow.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Bone conduction through your, through your skull, and it’s quiet enough that for the first time you can hear a part of your body that’s been along with you for the whole time you’ve been alive.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: That’s very cool. Could ...

transcript.author: Harper
transcript.text: Sorry—what? [Laughs.] That’s so crazy.

transcript.author: Jeffery DelViscio
transcript.text: I was just like, “F—, I can hear that.”

transcript.author: Harper
transcript.text: You’re just hearing your nervous system ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah, I actually ...

transcript.author: Harper
transcript.text: Okay, no worries.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: I’m glad we got that. That was ...

transcript.author: Harper
transcript.text: Sorry, carry on. I’m—I just—I’m so sorry [laughs].

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: That was really cool.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah, now I’m really distracted ’cause I can’t stop noticing it.

transcript.author: DelViscio
transcript.text: Listening to your nervous system ....

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And so that, that, actually, it’s starting to go away for you now ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Because of—that’s part of the fight-or-flight response because you’re hearing it through the ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Hypersensitive part of your stereocilia on your basilar membrane that are like, “Wake up! Are there tigers?” [Laughs.] Right? Like ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: [Laughs.] Could you show us some demonstrations to maybe help our listeners and viewers understand, like, how unique this space is? You’ve also let us borrow a very fancy mic so that we can present 360 stereo audio so that our, our listeners and viewers can, you know, experience being in the space as, as closely as we can approximate.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Yeah, absolutely. It’s subtle, and I hope that your viewers are wearing headphones.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: So how does this demonstration work?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Okay, so in order to demonstrate how much of the sound the room absorbs, I’m gonna sing a sinusoid, a pure tone, straight ahead. You’re gonna hear that as the loudest, most direct sound. I am not gonna change the volume of my sound at all, but I’m gonna turn around in a circle, and so as I turn you’re gonna hear the room absorbing more and more of my sound.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Okay.
[Starts singing and then stops to clear his throat.] Sorry, granola bar.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: [Laughs.] No worries.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: [Clears his throat and then starts singing while slowly moving in a circle.]

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: That is wild.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: So how does this one work?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Okay, so one of the kind of miraculous things about an anechoic chamber is it allows you to hear something that you can’t hear outside of the, of the chamber. And that’s that for every doubling of distance a sound source has to the listener there’s a cutting in half of the volume.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And so, and so I’m gonna speak to you at this level, and then I’m gonna double the distance, and you’re going to hear the same timbre, the same quality, the same emotional content as I’m talking now but just at half the volume. And then I’ll double it again, and you’ll hear even more of a falloff in the, in the volume.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Cool.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Okay, so this is me talking at the normal volume. And I’m going to move back double. [Moves backward.]
And this is me talking at that same volume; it’s just half as loud for you. [Moves backward.]
And this is me talking at the same volume, and it’s half as loud again.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: [Laughs.] Wow. Yeah, that is—it’s very weird to have it be the, you know, the, the level of a whisper but not sound like one [laughs].

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: So we’re obviously recording a podcast and a video right now. What kinds of technologies were created here that make this kind of multimedia possible?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: It’s kind of overwhelming, honestly. The “bit” of digital binary was invented here, and as an extension Claude Shannon and John Pierce invented pulse-code modulation, which is the way we record sound digitally. The charge-coupled device, the CCD, that captures video was invented here, the transistor—you know, the list goes on and on. Even The Jazz Singer, the first [feature-length] sound film [with synchronized sound for dialogue sequences] ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: The technology for that was developed by Western Electric—Bell Labs, how Bell Labs was founded, making it possible for us to synchronize sound and image for film.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: And what kind of experiments have happened in this chamber since then?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: A kind of remarkable amount of things that touch our individual lives. Like, we think about the Touch-Tone phone ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: The “bop beep bop bop bop bip bop.” The individual tones and their tuning are optimized for memorizing phone numbers ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And the acoustic research paired with psychology, or what we call psychoacoustics, was done in this room in order to, you know, help people figure out how to memorize the most phone numbers as the nation’s telephone grid got larger and larger ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Wow.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And it wasn’t just, you know, “Bronson 257,” right?
So in addition to that, you know, there was a, a fundamental research into synthesizing the sound of the human voice ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Right? We talk about microphone research and loudspeaker research, but that’s not the entirety of it. Behind that is signal-processing research, that’s about: How do you optimize a signal to go long-distance? And at first that was: How do you optimize a signal to go over a long run of copper wire, right? Reusing the telegraph system. And now in wireless: How do you, how do you encode a signal to minimize the amount of data taken up and maximize the quality of the voice?

You know, we think of science as being hard measurements and, and facts, and one of the things that’s remarkable about Bell Labs in the, in the ’60s and ’70s was human-factors research, like: How does it feel to use technology?

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And one of the convincing things in telephony was: How do you make sure, as you’re reducing the signal, that you’re not throwing away emotion ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: That you’re not throwing away recognition, that you can still recognize the person that you love on the other end of the line? And I think one of the things that this room actually shows us, and the audio for this podcast will actually reveal a little, is that the digital silence in cell phones is, is actually really dehumanizing ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: That, like, without the space around the signal, you, you lack context for the other person, and you’re like, “Are you there? Are you there?” And—because the absolute digital silence makes you feel, you know, quite alone.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah, that’s really interesting.
So I know that you are an artist-in-residence here.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: How did you get involved with the lab?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Sure, so I’ve been here since 2017, so this is my eighth year in the artist-in-residence role. When I first arrived I came in as a re—as part of a reboot of the historical Experiments in Art and Technology program, which was founded in the 1960s. And then in 2014 there was a reboot of, of, like, the role of artistic research at Bell Labs in, in one form or another. And because so many media technologies intersect with scientific research, the idea was: Let’s bring in artists, left-brain thinkers, to, to ask kind of divergent questions in a linear engineering space.

And so when I first came I was very active, moving lab to lab, asking questions of engineers and, and technical staff of what their research was and getting them to, to enter a dialogue to try to see what sort of divergent left-brain thinking might contribute to a kind of linear engineering research and development space.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Awesome. So what kind of stuff have you been working on?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: So I’ve been really interested in what I’m calling “the last 10 percent,” which is, like, in psychoacoustic research so much of the things that we know about the sound world were developed either for telephony or for the military ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: So: Can we get a signal efficiently across a line, or can we triangulate something in space—so sonar and radar and those sorts of things? In virtual reality and in artificial intelligence, now the question is: How do we pass the kind of uncanny valley of, like, this is almost real, but it’s not, right?
What I’m interested in is: What are the aspects of sound that are kind of soft factors, that are the human things that ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Make us feel like we’re situated, that make us understand the context? The auditory equivalent of depth perception ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Was something that was never, you know, looked at seriously in the initial sort of foundations research. And so I’ve been doing experiments around loudspeaker-array design and microphone-array design to try to think about what is hiding in the signal that our brain is processing that might not appear in the physical acoustics that give us a real sense of belonging—like, a sense of space. Like: “I am in this space, and, and, and it’s me and my body, not just my mind.”

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm, and I know that in addition to the kind of experiments that have been done here to contribute to technological advancements, there’s also been just sort of a lot of interesting art projects that have happened here ...

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: What are some of the, like, stranger, more interesting things that have been done in this room?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Sure. I mean, a lot of people don’t realize that the first time a computer sang was at Bell Labs, right?

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: So at the end of 2001: A Space Odyssey, when HAL is singing—is dying ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And he sings, “Daisy ...”
[CLIP: HAL from 2001: A Space Odyssey sings: “Daisy, Daisy / Give me your answer, do.”]

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: That was heard by Arthur C. Clarke when he did a tour of Bell Labs ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And then was incorporated into the movie because it was the first time a computer sang, so the idea of giving the computer some human character came from trying to figure out speech-synthesis problems. Because if we could understand the nature of the way that speech was synthesized digitally, we could initiate the revolution of automated telephone answering, right ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Like, or the synthesized voices that AI responds with. All of that foundational research was done in spaces like this, and it was done first by asking a computer to sing.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Very cool. And I know somebody brought a grand piano in here. We learned that as reassurance that the wire floor was not gonna give out underneath us [laughs].

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: What was that about? Because, you know, I feel like acoustically, this is objectively not great ...

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: To make music in.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: I wasn’t around for the grand-piano experiments, but at the start of my residency I—we had a artist-in-residence partner, collaborator, the International Contemporary Ensemble, and we brought a 12-person chamber orchestra into this room ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And a four-person orchestra—or, like, ensemble—into the adjacent room, and we were able to transmit the anechoic sounds, the sounds without reverberation ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: To an adjacent space and apply a new space in real time. So we could dial in Carnegie Hall ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Or dial in an outdoor forest or dial in, you know, the best shower you’ve ever sung in, right? And so that ability to, like, “act” on signals that haven’t yet been touched by space ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Helps us understand how to process the signals that give us a sense of, like, where sound is coming from.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: I feel like a lot of the sort of mainstream conversation about anechoic chambers is that it feels really freaky to be in them ...

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Mm, yeah.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: And you hear some, like, probably hyperbolic stories about, like ...

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: A sense of panic. Why is it that it feels so strange for us to be in here? And I’m also curious: How do you feel about being in the space?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: I love being in it.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: You know, I think in an, in—like, we talk about the attention economy in that, like, we’re all on our phones, and we’ve got earbuds in all the time, and we sleep to white noise, and we sleep to music. One of the remarkable things about this room, and the, you know, the people who are doing the recording around us right now are beginning to experience it, when you’re in here for 20 minutes, your fight-or-flight response that’s active all the time—like, if you step your foot off of a curb and you hear a bicycle messenger ding their bell and you pull your foot back automatically ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: That automatic retraction of your foot is happening because there’s a, there’s a, a jumper between your auditory cortex and your—and the part of your brain that’s responsible for your physical motion, and it retracts your foot without you having to tell your foot to retract.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: The fact that it does that is because the brain is capable of that precognitive response because we’re in a heightened mode of attention with our ears, and we ignore [roughly] 85 percent of the, of the sound of the world all the time. Otherwise, we’d be, you know, subject to the same kind of sensory-processing disorders that, that, you know, are so common, right? When you’re in here for 20 minutes, the little hair cells on your basilar membrane inside of your ear relax, and it gets 10 percent quieter.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And I think there’s that moment where you’re like, “Where’s the stimulus? Where’s the stimulus?” And that feels panicking, in the same way as, like, “Why hasn’t anybody responded to my text?”

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And I think if you just—if you change your perception to a longer arc of, “Where is my body right now?” you start to realize, like, “My heart rate’s lowered, lymphatic production slowed down. My breathing is, is slower.” And you can center into a kind of space that’s really sort of unheard of in the 21st century.

I hold two roles: I’m the artist-in-residence at Nokia Bell Labs, and I’m the director of the historic Computer Music Center at Columbia University. And in both of those places I’m interested in the same thing: what I’m calling sort of “sensory computing” or “speculative acoustics.” Like, this idea that there’s—there—it’s important for computers to not just process text and language but for computers to understand the world around them with the same level of resolution that we do, right?

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: If we want to expect intelligence out of machines, we don’t just know things from memorizing things off of—out of books and off the Internet. We know things by walking around the world. And so for me the intersection between engineering and, and the real world is this fascinating place where the resolution gets clearer and clearer the more you kind of attune the rest of the senses to catch up to our ability to process text, right, and vision, which has led the charge for so many years.

I think the solution to so many of the, of the questions of, like, what the next 100 years is going to feel like in terms of the way we interact with computers are gonna come down to how embodied we feel and then, as an extension, how safe we feel around the computer.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: So I understand that this facility is, is gonna be closing down in the next few years.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: What do you think you’re, you’re gonna take away from having worked in this space for as long as you have?

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: I’m, I’m tempted to say something sort of profound about my own practice and, and, and its effect on my practice, which has been sort of immeasurable, right? Like, having the ability to record an absolutely dry audio for someone who composes electronic music is, like, unmeasurably positive, right?

But for me the real impact has been watching and leading dozens of school groups through, from elementary school through college, students from Harvard and students from Rutgers, students from Ramapo College and students from, from Carnegie Mellon, coming in and for the first time experiencing something absolutely new, right?

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Like, that sense of awe at the kind of sublime—like, the reason we sit in front of mountains and stare at the ocean—this is just the same but for the absence of stimulus ...

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: And I think for a lot of people it’s a real revelation that maybe, maybe technology writes on us a little bit too much, and it’s time to kind of shake the Etch A Sketch gray and start writing over again.

transcript.author: Feltman
transcript.text: Well, thank you so much for taking the time to chat with us and for, you know, showing us around, telling us how this room works. It’s been really cool.

transcript.author: Cluett
transcript.text: Yeah, it’s my pleasure. Thank you. Thank you for having me.

lines: This experiment just pops a balloon. And normally, when a balloon would pop, you’d hear [makes an exploding noise]—the whole room just kind of expand, right?
[Pops a balloon inside a normal room, making a loud noise.]
Ooh!
[Laughs.]
[Laughs.] Yeah.
Pretty loud.
Yeah, pretty loud [laughs].
But in this room there’s none of that. So you’re gonna hear it as a very sharp sound that just disappears completely.
[Pops a balloon inside an anechoic chamber, making a sharp noise that dissipates immediately.]
Ooh!
Welcome to the anechoic chamber. Watch your step.
Whoa [laughs].
Wow, it is already super quiet in here [laughs].
And it’s gonna get even more quiet when we close the door.
Cool.
[Walks to the chamber entrance and closes the outer and inner doors.] How’s that?
It did get a lot more quiet, yeah [laughs].

Welcome to Science Quickly. I’m Rachel Feltman, and today I’m here with Seth Cluett at Nokia Bell Labs. And you may notice if you’re listening to this, or if you’re watching it, that there’s some interesting stuff going on with the sound. Seth, would you tell us more about why that is?

Yeah, so we are in the historic anechoic chamber at Bell Labs. It is a room that absorbs 99.999 percent of sound-wave propagation and eliminates sound from the outside almost entirely. It is anechoic, meaning it lacks echo. So an anechoic chamber is intended to absorb as close to 100 percent of incidental reflection as you can possibly do.

This room, as you kinda look around, is a [roughly] 30-by-30 cube with a wire mesh a third up from the floor. You might ask yourself, like, “Why is it a third up from the floor, not in the center?” And the answer is that you want the experiment to happen as close to the middle as possible.
Mm.
Because the one place where it’s scientifically feasible to measure sound exactly is in the center of the cube because the distance to the walls and the reflections are equal in that case.

The building is a shell that has [roughly] two-foot-thick walls and an air gap and then another wall, and that air gap separates the sound waves from the outside. And then inside the room there are these [roughly] four-foot wedge panels in groups of three in an offset kind of orthogonal pattern—a, a grid pattern. They capture the sound waves before they’re able to reflect back. So they, they come to a kind of inverted point in the inside of the wall, and when sound gets into that point it kind of bounces back and forth on the diagonal, and by the time it gets to the outside of the wedge there’s no more sound energy left to reflect.
Mm, so when you’re in this totally quiet space what kinds of things can you feel and perceive in your body?
Yeah, I think most people feel a kind of pressure against their ears first.
Mm.

It sort of feels like the air is heavy or thick. Then, then you start to notice a kind of low pulse and realize that’s your heart beating and you can hear it in the air, in, in addition to through your body. And for most people you can even hear a high pitch, and you think, “Oh, I have tinnitus,” or “There’s something wrong with my hearing.” You’re actually hearing your nervous system ...
Wow.
Bone conduction through your, through your skull, and it’s quiet enough that for the first time you can hear a part of your body that’s been along with you for the whole time you’ve been alive.
That’s very cool. Could ...
Sorry—what? [Laughs.] That’s so crazy.
I was just like, “F—, I can hear that.”
You’re just hearing your nervous system ...
Yeah, I actually ...
Okay, no worries.
I’m glad we got that. That was ...
Sorry, carry on. I’m—I just—I’m so sorry [laughs].
That was really cool.
Yeah, now I’m really distracted ’cause I can’t stop noticing it.
Listening to your nervous system ....
And so that, that, actually, it’s starting to go away for you now ...
Right.
Because of—that’s part of the fight-or-flight response because you’re hearing it through the ...
Yeah.
Hypersensitive part of your stereocilia on your basilar membrane that are like, “Wake up! Are there tigers?” [Laughs.] Right? Like ...

[Laughs.] Could you show us some demonstrations to maybe help our listeners and viewers understand, like, how unique this space is? You’ve also let us borrow a very fancy mic so that we can present 360 stereo audio so that our, our listeners and viewers can, you know, experience being in the space as, as closely as we can approximate.
Yeah, absolutely. It’s subtle, and I hope that your viewers are wearing headphones.
So how does this demonstration work?

Okay, so in order to demonstrate how much of the sound the room absorbs, I’m gonna sing a sinusoid, a pure tone, straight ahead. You’re gonna hear that as the loudest, most direct sound. I am not gonna change the volume of my sound at all, but I’m gonna turn around in a circle, and so as I turn you’re gonna hear the room absorbing more and more of my sound.
Okay.
Okay.
[Starts singing and then stops to clear his throat.] Sorry, granola bar.
[Laughs.] No worries.
[Clears his throat and then starts singing while slowly moving in a circle.]
That is wild.
Yeah.
So how does this one work?

Okay, so one of the kind of miraculous things about an anechoic chamber is it allows you to hear something that you can’t hear outside of the, of the chamber. And that’s that for every doubling of distance a sound source has to the listener there’s a cutting in half of the volume.
Mm.

And so, and so I’m gonna speak to you at this level, and then I’m gonna double the distance, and you’re going to hear the same timbre, the same quality, the same emotional content as I’m talking now but just at half the volume. And then I’ll double it again, and you’ll hear even more of a falloff in the, in the volume.
Cool.
Okay, so this is me talking at the normal volume. And I’m going to move back double. [Moves backward.]
And this is me talking at that same volume; it’s just half as loud for you. [Moves backward.]
And this is me talking at the same volume, and it’s half as loud again.
[Laughs.] Wow. Yeah, that is—it’s very weird to have it be the, you know, the, the level of a whisper but not sound like one [laughs].
So we’re obviously recording a podcast and a video right now. What kinds of technologies were created here that make this kind of multimedia possible?

It’s kind of overwhelming, honestly. The “bit” of digital binary was invented here, and as an extension Claude Shannon and John Pierce invented pulse-code modulation, which is the way we record sound digitally. The charge-coupled device, the CCD, that captures video was invented here, the transistor—you know, the list goes on and on. Even The Jazz Singer, the first [feature-length] sound film [with synchronized sound for dialogue sequences] ...
Mm.
The technology for that was developed by Western Electric—Bell Labs, how Bell Labs was founded, making it possible for us to synchronize sound and image for film.
And what kind of experiments have happened in this chamber since then?
A kind of remarkable amount of things that touch our individual lives. Like, we think about the Touch-Tone phone ...
Mm-hmm.
The “bop beep bop bop bop bip bop.” The individual tones and their tuning are optimized for memorizing phone numbers ...
Mm.

And the acoustic research paired with psychology, or what we call psychoacoustics, was done in this room in order to, you know, help people figure out how to memorize the most phone numbers as the nation’s telephone grid got larger and larger ...
Wow.
And it wasn’t just, you know, “Bronson 257,” right?
So in addition to that, you know, there was a, a fundamental research into synthesizing the sound of the human voice ...
Mm.

Right? We talk about microphone research and loudspeaker research, but that’s not the entirety of it. Behind that is signal-processing research, that’s about: How do you optimize a signal to go long-distance? And at first that was: How do you optimize a signal to go over a long run of copper wire, right? Reusing the telegraph system. And now in wireless: How do you, how do you encode a signal to minimize the amount of data taken up and maximize the quality of the voice?

You know, we think of science as being hard measurements and, and facts, and one of the things that’s remarkable about Bell Labs in the, in the ’60s and ’70s was human-factors research, like: How does it feel to use technology?
Mm.
And one of the convincing things in telephony was: How do you make sure, as you’re reducing the signal, that you’re not throwing away emotion ...
Mm.

That you’re not throwing away recognition, that you can still recognize the person that you love on the other end of the line? And I think one of the things that this room actually shows us, and the audio for this podcast will actually reveal a little, is that the digital silence in cell phones is, is actually really dehumanizing ...
Mm.

That, like, without the space around the signal, you, you lack context for the other person, and you’re like, “Are you there? Are you there?” And—because the absolute digital silence makes you feel, you know, quite alone.
Yeah, that’s really interesting.
So I know that you are an artist-in-residence here.
Mm-hmm.
How did you get involved with the lab?

Sure, so I’ve been here since 2017, so this is my eighth year in the artist-in-residence role. When I first arrived I came in as a re—as part of a reboot of the historical Experiments in Art and Technology program, which was founded in the 1960s. And then in 2014 there was a reboot of, of, like, the role of artistic research at Bell Labs in, in one form or another. And because so many media technologies intersect with scientific research, the idea was: Let’s bring in artists, left-brain thinkers, to, to ask kind of divergent questions in a linear engineering space.

And so when I first came I was very active, moving lab to lab, asking questions of engineers and, and technical staff of what their research was and getting them to, to enter a dialogue to try to see what sort of divergent left-brain thinking might contribute to a kind of linear engineering research and development space.
Awesome. So what kind of stuff have you been working on?

So I’ve been really interested in what I’m calling “the last 10 percent,” which is, like, in psychoacoustic research so much of the things that we know about the sound world were developed either for telephony or for the military ...
Mm-hmm.

So: Can we get a signal efficiently across a line, or can we triangulate something in space—so sonar and radar and those sorts of things? In virtual reality and in artificial intelligence, now the question is: How do we pass the kind of uncanny valley of, like, this is almost real, but it’s not, right?
What I’m interested in is: What are the aspects of sound that are kind of soft factors, that are the human things that ...
Mm.
Make us feel like we’re situated, that make us understand the context? The auditory equivalent of depth perception ...
Mm-hmm.

Was something that was never, you know, looked at seriously in the initial sort of foundations research. And so I’ve been doing experiments around loudspeaker-array design and microphone-array design to try to think about what is hiding in the signal that our brain is processing that might not appear in the physical acoustics that give us a real sense of belonging—like, a sense of space. Like: “I am in this space, and, and, and it’s me and my body, not just my mind.”

Mm, and I know that in addition to the kind of experiments that have been done here to contribute to technological advancements, there’s also been just sort of a lot of interesting art projects that have happened here ...
Mm-hmm.
What are some of the, like, stranger, more interesting things that have been done in this room?
Sure. I mean, a lot of people don’t realize that the first time a computer sang was at Bell Labs, right?
Mm.
So at the end of 2001: A Space Odyssey, when HAL is singing—is dying ...
Yeah.
And he sings, “Daisy ...”
[CLIP: HAL from 2001: A Space Odyssey sings: “Daisy, Daisy / Give me your answer, do.”]
That was heard by Arthur C. Clarke when he did a tour of Bell Labs ...
Mm.

And then was incorporated into the movie because it was the first time a computer sang, so the idea of giving the computer some human character came from trying to figure out speech-synthesis problems. Because if we could understand the nature of the way that speech was synthesized digitally, we could initiate the revolution of automated telephone answering, right ...
Mm.
Like, or the synthesized voices that AI responds with. All of that foundational research was done in spaces like this, and it was done first by asking a computer to sing.
Very cool. And I know somebody brought a grand piano in here. We learned that as reassurance that the wire floor was not gonna give out underneath us [laughs].
Yeah.
What was that about? Because, you know, I feel like acoustically, this is objectively not great ...
Mm.
To make music in.

I wasn’t around for the grand-piano experiments, but at the start of my residency I—we had a artist-in-residence partner, collaborator, the International Contemporary Ensemble, and we brought a 12-person chamber orchestra into this room ...
Mm.
And a four-person orchestra—or, like, ensemble—into the adjacent room, and we were able to transmit the anechoic sounds, the sounds without reverberation ...
Mm-hmm.
To an adjacent space and apply a new space in real time. So we could dial in Carnegie Hall ...
Hmm.
Or dial in an outdoor forest or dial in, you know, the best shower you’ve ever sung in, right? And so that ability to, like, “act” on signals that haven’t yet been touched by space ...
Mm.
Helps us understand how to process the signals that give us a sense of, like, where sound is coming from.
I feel like a lot of the sort of mainstream conversation about anechoic chambers is that it feels really freaky to be in them ...
Mm, yeah.
And you hear some, like, probably hyperbolic stories about, like ...
Right.
A sense of panic. Why is it that it feels so strange for us to be in here? And I’m also curious: How do you feel about being in the space?
I love being in it.
Yeah.

You know, I think in an, in—like, we talk about the attention economy in that, like, we’re all on our phones, and we’ve got earbuds in all the time, and we sleep to white noise, and we sleep to music. One of the remarkable things about this room, and the, you know, the people who are doing the recording around us right now are beginning to experience it, when you’re in here for 20 minutes, your fight-or-flight response that’s active all the time—like, if you step your foot off of a curb and you hear a bicycle messenger ding their bell and you pull your foot back automatically ...
Mm-hmm.

That automatic retraction of your foot is happening because there’s a, there’s a, a jumper between your auditory cortex and your—and the part of your brain that’s responsible for your physical motion, and it retracts your foot without you having to tell your foot to retract.
Mm.

The fact that it does that is because the brain is capable of that precognitive response because we’re in a heightened mode of attention with our ears, and we ignore [roughly] 85 percent of the, of the sound of the world all the time. Otherwise, we’d be, you know, subject to the same kind of sensory-processing disorders that, that, you know, are so common, right? When you’re in here for 20 minutes, the little hair cells on your basilar membrane inside of your ear relax, and it gets 10 percent quieter.
Mm.
And I think there’s that moment where you’re like, “Where’s the stimulus? Where’s the stimulus?” And that feels panicking, in the same way as, like, “Why hasn’t anybody responded to my text?”
Mm.

And I think if you just—if you change your perception to a longer arc of, “Where is my body right now?” you start to realize, like, “My heart rate’s lowered, lymphatic production slowed down. My breathing is, is slower.” And you can center into a kind of space that’s really sort of unheard of in the 21st century.

I hold two roles: I’m the artist-in-residence at Nokia Bell Labs, and I’m the director of the historic Computer Music Center at Columbia University. And in both of those places I’m interested in the same thing: what I’m calling sort of “sensory computing” or “speculative acoustics.” Like, this idea that there’s—there—it’s important for computers to not just process text and language but for computers to understand the world around them with the same level of resolution that we do, right?
Mm-hmm.

If we want to expect intelligence out of machines, we don’t just know things from memorizing things off of—out of books and off the Internet. We know things by walking around the world. And so for me the intersection between engineering and, and the real world is this fascinating place where the resolution gets clearer and clearer the more you kind of attune the rest of the senses to catch up to our ability to process text, right, and vision, which has led the charge for so many years.

I think the solution to so many of the, of the questions of, like, what the next 100 years is going to feel like in terms of the way we interact with computers are gonna come down to how embodied we feel and then, as an extension, how safe we feel around the computer.
So I understand that this facility is, is gonna be closing down in the next few years.
Mm-hmm.
What do you think you’re, you’re gonna take away from having worked in this space for as long as you have?

I’m, I’m tempted to say something sort of profound about my own practice and, and, and its effect on my practice, which has been sort of immeasurable, right? Like, having the ability to record an absolutely dry audio for someone who composes electronic music is, like, unmeasurably positive, right?

But for me the real impact has been watching and leading dozens of school groups through, from elementary school through college, students from Harvard and students from Rutgers, students from Ramapo College and students from, from Carnegie Mellon, coming in and for the first time experiencing something absolutely new, right?
Yeah.
Like, that sense of awe at the kind of sublime—like, the reason we sit in front of mountains and stare at the ocean—this is just the same but for the absence of stimulus ...
Mm-hmm.

And I think for a lot of people it’s a real revelation that maybe, maybe technology writes on us a little bit too much, and it’s time to kind of shake the Etch A Sketch gray and start writing over again.
Well, thank you so much for taking the time to chat with us and for, you know, showing us around, telling us how this room works. It’s been really cool.
Yeah, it’s my pleasure. Thank you. Thank you for having me.
